1. Which of the following strategies is least likely to improve retirement security?
  • Saving an additional 3% of salary in the five years prior to retirement
  • Working for two years past the planned retirement date
  • Deferring Social Security benefits for two years longer than originally planned
Good!
Brush up on your knowledge

Because five years doesn’t give your money much time to compound, the benefits of saving more right before you retire are minimal. Say you make $50,000 per year. Saving an extra 3% would mean an extra $1,500 per year or $125 per month. If we plug these numbers into Grow’s compound interest calculator using a more conservative 5% annual return, you’d wind up with an additional $8,500 at the start of retirement, $7,500 of which you contributed yourself.

Meanwhile, delaying retirement two years has multiple benefits. It gives you extra time to save and your money extra time to compound. Retirement savings of $500,000 could grow to more than $550,000 in just two years, without any additional contributions.

And for every year you wait to receive Social Security benefits from your full retirement age to age 70, your annual benefit increases by 8%.

2. Which one of the following statements concerning the federal income tax treatment of distributions to a 65-year-old retiree is true?
  • Distributions from a traditional IRA are generally taxed as long-term capital gains
  • Distributions from a traditional IRA for the 65-year-old are generally subject to an additional 10% penalty tax
  • Distributions from a Roth IRA are generally tax-free
That's correct.
No.
Because you put money into a Roth IRA post-tax, the distributions you receive from it are tax-free. On the other hand, distributions from a traditional IRA are taxed as income since the contributions are pre-tax.
3. Converting a portion of a traditional IRA into a Roth IRA is a good idea this year if:
  • You have more taxable income than usual and your marginal tax rate is higher than normal
  • You have a big tax deduction this year and your marginal tax rate is lower than normal
  • The value of the assets in your IRA have remained the same for 10 years
That's correct.
No.
Experts recommend investing in a Roth IRA if you’re in a lower tax bracket. While you’ll pay taxes on the money now, you’ll likely save in the long term, as your tax rate could be higher when you’re older and making more money. “If you’re younger and in a lower tax bracket, you should shovel everything you can into a Roth account,” Ed Slott, a certified public accountant and founder of Ed Slott & Co., told Grow earlier this year.
4. Suppose that the interest rate on your savings account was 2% per year and inflation was 4% per year. After one year, would you be able to buy more than, exactly the same as, or less than today with the money in this account?
  • More than today
  • Exactly the same as today
  • Less than today
That's correct.
No.

Inflation means prices are going up on items you buy, which means your purchasing power, or the value of your money, goes down. A 4% inflation rate means the purchasing power of the money in your account decreases by 4%.

Since the inflation rate is higher than the interest rate, the value of your money is actually going down. This is why experts recommend you invest rather than save your money for long-term goals like retirement.

5. True or false: Buying a single company’s stock usually provides a safer return than a stock mutual fund.
  • True
  • False
That's correct.
No.
When you invest in a mutual fund, ETF, or an index fund, you’re buying a basket of investments. That spreads out the risk so your investment isn’t dependent on the fortunes of a single company. And even though individual stock prices can fluctuate wildly, the market has a proven track record of going up over time.
6. True or false: Exchange traded funds generally have higher expenses than actively managed mutual funds.
  • True
  • False
That's correct.
No.
Most exchange-traded funds, or ETFs, are index funds that track an index like the S&P 500 and are bought and sold like stocks. Actively managed mutual funds have someone at the helm who is crafting strategy, making the cost to manage the fund higher.
